fields.description:
We had a cloud in HA mode (2xCLC-w, 2xCC-SC, 26xNCs) where we had a low heap memory fault after about 1 day of operations:

{code}
************************************************************************
  ERR-1004 2013-05-11 13:55:22 Java is running very low on heap space memory.

   condition: Running very low on heap space memory in Java.
       cause: Java garbage collection is not able to reclaim enough memory.
   initiator: cloud
    location: Cloud
  resolution: 
        1) Ensure that the CLOUD_OPTS variable set in eucalyptus.conf includes 
           a value for -Xmx. Set or increase this value as necessary: by 
           default, it should be at least 1GB or 1/4 of the physical memory, 
           whichever is smaller. This value can be expressed in bytes, or as '1G'.
        2) Restart the cloud application.
        3) If this condition continues despite a high value for -Xmx, it may be 
           necessary to add more physical memory to the machine.
      
************************************************************************
{code}

the cloud was lightly used and at the time was running about 50 instances. The churn seemed pretty low, and there was only one EMI loaded on the system at that time. 

There has been some talk about EUCA-6031 been caused by a memory leak, but I am not sure if high CPU usage was observed on this cloud before it went under.
fields.summary: low on heap space memory after few hours of operation

comments.body: Linked to EUCA-4741 and EUCA-3994 after a chat with [~dshekhawat].
EUCA-5908 could be a factor if something is writing to the JVM system out or err.
The issue in EUCA-5908 is retention of log messages in memory, you would not see these messages in the log files.
Got it. Is there a way for us to inspect what logs the CLC keeps in memory? In other words, is there anything we can do to validate that this was the issue we are seeing?

[~graziano], the proper way to determine the root cause, is to inspect the hprof file.  Do you have access to the hprof file from the customer's system? The hprof file is located in the standard eucalyptus log file location.
[~kedwards] please look at the SUP ticket for the hprof. Sorry it took so long to collect it.
Thanks [~sjones]! So this issue is not related to EUCA-5908. Removed the link. [~kedwards] let me know if you find anything.
This is definitely a connection leak. I am seeing 402MB out of a total 1000MB being help by org.postgresql.jdbc4.Jdbc4Connection in the .hprof output. I will investigate as to the root cause
[~graziano] Is the customer able to reproduce this issue consistently or did they see this just once?
[~mmunn1] to the best of my knowledge it happened few times in a row (at least to the best of my knowledge). Since then I'm not aware of them seeing the problem again. I will check to confirm though.
I am looking at the testing branch, the code I am looking at is the same as 3.2.2.. Make sure you are looking at the begin in Entities$CascadingTx$TxState.begin() line: 903
Thank you [~mmunn1], fix looks good to me.
We have not been able to reproduce this in house, so there is no testcase.
